title: Crash fix: Rename logging function error => logError, to avoid being shadowed by kotlin.util.error.
message:
Crash fix: Rename logging function error => logError, to avoid being shadowed by kotlin.util.error.

kotlin.util.* functions are imported by default, and kotlin.util.error in
particular simply throws an IllegalStateException, causing the cryptic crash
seen in Crashlytics issue 9.

title: Fix UI not loading after configuration change (e.g., rotation).
message:
Fix UI not loading after configuration change (e.g., rotation).

This happened because we only called observe() on LiveData the first time
onCreate() was called, but not subsequently. This is incorrect according to the
docs.

However, to prevent registering multiple identical Observers for the same
Activity instance, we store a reference to the Observer and reuse it if it
already exists.

Quoting from LiveData#observe() docs:

> When it is destroyed, LiveData removes references to the observer & the owner.

And further below, in the context of multiple observe() calls:

> If the given owner, observer tuple is already in the list, the observe() call
> is ignored. If the observer is already in the list with another owner,
> LiveData throws an IllegalArgumentException.

title: Fix a memory leak caused by always adding WebViewFragments instead of replacing.
message:
Fix a memory leak caused by always adding WebViewFragments instead of replacing.

There's another memory leak but its root cause is in OnePlus's own code :rage:. See
https://github.com/square/leakcanary/issues/724.

title: Fix description/code not updating after onStop()/onStart() cycle.
message:
Fix description/code not updating after onStop()/onStart() cycle.

This happened because the LiveData.observe() and removeObserver() calls were
called asymmetrically (the former in onCreateView and the latter in onStop).
I've deleted the removeObserver call since it's not needed - LiveData takes a
LifecycleOwner argument and:

1. does not call the observer if it's not in the STARTED or RESUMED states, and,
2. unsubscribes the observer if the Lifecycle is destroyed

See the docs for more:
https://developer.android.com/topic/libraries/architecture/livedata.html
